awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding the Coupling between Clouds and Midlatitude Dynamics at Synoptic and Global Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
The typical pattern of clouds around a mid-latitude cyclone features high clouds east of the center and along the trailing cold front, and low clouds in the cold sector to the west. This general pattern has been known since the 1920s but the role of the clouds in cyclone evolution, and the effects of the cloud pattern on atmospheric circulation and climate, are still under study. The topic is of practical as well as scientific interest as clouds can only be represented in approximate form in current weather and climate models, and cloud errors limit the quality of simulations and forecasts. Results of the work have direct bearing on the quality of weather forecasts and climate projections used to provide guidance to decision makers and the public. In addition, the educational activities supported under this CAREER award advance science teaching at the high school, college, and graduate levels.

The research focuses specifically on cloud radiative effects (CREs), meaning the cooling caused by clouds as they reflect shortwave solar radiation back to space and the warming effect when they intercept outgoing longwave radiation emitted by the earth. In the deep clouds found in the eastern sector the longwave and shortwave effects show large cancellation, while shortwave cooling dominates in the low clouds on the western side. Preliminary work by the PI shows that, at least in the Southern Hemisphere, CRE evolves over the lifecycle of the cyclone, forming a north-south dipole during the decay phase with warming on the equatorward side. The north-south CRE dipole in the decaying stage could affect the meridional temperature gradient along the SH storm track, possibly helping to reestablish the meridional temperature contrast after cyclone passage and thus promoting further cyclone activity or influencing the latitude of the upper-level jet stream. The radiative effect of clouds around cyclones could also influence the behavior of low-frequency climate variability and secular climate change, both of which involve latitudinal shifts of jet streams and storm tracks. The work considers the dynamic and thermodynamic controls on the clouds as well as the influence of clouds on the midlatitude circulation. It is conducted through a combination of observational analysis and model simulation.

The educational component of the project includes efforts at the high school, college, and graduate level. At the high school level, the PI works with education experts at the Center for Teaching Excellence on the UVA campus, the Environmental Studies Academy (ESA) at Western Albermarle High School, and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR). The goal is to develop a teaching module to introduce high school students to the role of clouds in the climate system. The module will be disseminated nationally through the web portal at UCAR. Undergraduate education is promoted through the development of a course on climate modeling and analysis. One issue addressed by the course is the lack of computer skills commonly found among undergraduates, which limits their ability to engage in scientific research. The course involves training in the use of data analysis software and hands-on projects conducted by groups of two to three students. Students from the class are recruited to conduct research in the summers, with emphasis on the recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities. On the graduate level, the project supports two students who, in addition to their research and classwork, serve as mentors for undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Clouds represent one of the largest uncertainties in climate prediction, primarily because they occur on smaller scales than can be represented in present-day climate models.  Thus, it is critical to understand the relationship between clouds and their large-scale meteorological drivers (cloud controlling factors), which are better resolved in climate models.  At the same time, clouds and their associated effects on atmospheric radiation impact the temperature structure of the atmosphere, which can modify the location and strength of winds and weather systems.  This project focused on better understanding these two-way interactions between clouds and weather systems in Earth's midlatitudes (30-60 degrees latitude).

Midlatitude clouds are highly sensitive to a number of cloud controlling factors.  For example, deep clouds occur in frontal regions of midlatitude low-pressure systems (cyclones) where there is strong ascent, and shallow low-level clouds occur where there is descent, temperatures increase with height above the ocean surface, and winds are transporting in cold air.  A key finding of this project was that the day-to-day variability of midlatitude clouds is overly sensitive to vertical motion in climate models, leading to clouds that excessively brighten in frontal regions of midlatitude cyclones and excessively dim in high-pressure systems.  This is in contrast to previous studies that have focused on the cold-air sector of midlatitude cyclones as being the prominent source of model bias.  Additionally, results from this project have shown that models underestimate the observed dependence of midlatitude low cloud cover on horizontal and vertical temperature variations above the ocean surface.  To improve understanding of these processes, the project has provided observational benchmarks for how various types of midlatitude clouds (deep storm clouds, mid-level clouds, stratocumulus, shallow cumulus, etc.), as identified from satellite data, respond to perturbations in cloud controlling factors.  These observational relationships have the potential to be used to predict changes in the prevalence of different cloud types with climate variability and change, relying only on future changes in meteorology and not on climate models' ability to directly simulate clouds.  This is important because 1) individual cloud types have different effects on Earth's energy budget and thus the planet's temperature and 2) climate models more faithfully represent large-scale meteorology in comparison to small-scale cloud processes.   

To understand the impacts of clouds on midlatitude weather systems, idealized climate model experiments (cloud locking) were performed.  These experiments disabled the high-frequency interactions between the radiative effects of clouds and weather systems.  These experiments revealed that the radiative effects of clouds can reduce the intensity and duration of midlatitude cyclones by a modest amount.  A different form of idealized model experiments was performed to investigate why climate models struggle with accurately representing the observed persistence of the midlatitude jet stream (i.e., how long the jet stream and associated midlatitude storm tracks remain in an anomalously northward or southward position).  Preliminary results suggest that the representation of low cloud cover and its radiative effects might be responsible in part for this bias, suggesting that improved representation of low cloud cover might improve the representation of midlatitude weather variability in climate models.  Overall, the results imply that a proper coupling among clouds, radiation, and atmospheric dynamics may be necessary to accurately simulate midlatitude weather systems, and that improving the representation of clouds in climate models may help to provide more accurate future projections of midlatitude weather systems.

The educational component of the project led to the development of an online high school teaching module on clouds and climate that is now freely available online to educators and students from a diverse range of backgrounds from across the United States and the world.  The module introduces high school students to the role of clouds in climate and climate change, connecting high school instruction with this project's scientific research.  This teaching module builds student understanding of the science while developing student skill with science and engineering practices.  The teaching box leverages the multi-scale perspective of the research project, presenting linkages between familiar everyday cloud and weather systems and the large-scale processes that are necessary to understand global climate change. 

Another activity for the educational component of the project is that the PI co-developed/co-taught a class at the University of Virginia on Climate Modeling and Analysis.  The class introduces undergraduate and graduate students to the physical processes that underlie global climate models, as well as the analysis techniques to use global climate model output to answer research questions.  The class is intended to increase the accessibility of global climate model output to students from fields who traditionally have less experience in working with global climate models.    

Finally, the project contributed to the mentoring and training of three graduate students and helped fund the participation of three undergraduate students in summer research, including two from the Virginia-North Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation Summer Research Program.
